@Rigel Velez, thank you for your response!

In statistics, there can only be a cause-and-effect relationship if we perform an experiment.  We would need to randomly assign a large group of individuals to one of two groups: where all members of one group are assigned to smoke and all members of the other group are assigned to not to smoke.  We would collect income information from all members of each group for many years. Then we would compare the average income for each group. Given what we know about the harmfulness of smoking, such an experiment would be unethical. When an experiment cannot be conducted, we can use observational studies to learn about the relationship between variables like smoking and income.

The data represented in this graph comes from an observational study.  There is no cause-and-effect, but rather an association.

You also mentioned wondering how many people were in each income bracket.  That data is not provided, but since the source is the CDC, the total number of observations was likely VERY high.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Good morning again, Graph Analyzers –

About an hour ago, I wrote about Correlation vs. Association.  We say there is a correlation between two variables if both are quantitative.  Otherwise, we say that there is an association between any two variables, but in this case, for a quantitative variable (household income) and a categorical variable (smoking).

Now, let’s talk about if having a lower household income CAUSES people to smoke.  Or, if alternatively, if smoking CAUSES one to have a lower household income.  Both of these are described here as cause-and-effect relationships.
In statistics, there can only be a cause-and-effect relationship if we perform an experiment.  We would need to randomly assign a large group of individuals to one of two groups: where all members of one group are assigned to smoke and all members of the other group are assigned to not to smoke.  We would collect income information from all members of each group for many years. Then we would compare the average income for each group. Given what we know about the harmfulness of smoking, such an experiment would be unethical. When an experiment cannot be conducted, we can use observational studies to learn about the relationship between variables like smoking and income.

The data represented in this graph comes from an observational study.  There is NO cause-and-effect, but rather an ASSOCIATION!
